I wish they would be as thick as the camera bump because I hate it... would allow to stuff more inside like bigger battery and so on... and doesn't really add too much to the size anyway...  also our eyes see fluent from 30hz... as it's normal some with a bit higher and some a bit lesser frames... that's the restriction of your brain handling the incoming information of our eyes... so why is everyone hunting for more fps? yes above 60 it gets stupid as hell... what would be more important than hunting for more fps and even artificially boosting it like NVIDIA would be to remove frames rates breaking down due to loading issues and so on... this is what breaks the immersion of a fluent frame rate... but the industry is the industry and needs to sell everyone more and more stuff... I have quite a few friends claiming that higher FPS are useful and you can feel the difference - but when I switched the game to 60 fps max and didn't tell him he explained me how fluid the game was compared to low frame rates... they usually don't realize it and only when pointing out it's 60 FPS they get confused... it's a placebo effect at best... why 60 though? because a) people are different and b) there are always minor fluctuations in FPS... the biggest issue is though when the FPS drop below our fluid received threshold...

1- Camera's are performing a bit better than Oneplus13 even with the downgraded hardware. 2- Processor chip is stronger now than before 3- Its back has extraordinary durability, only a diamond can put a scratch on it, moreover it is ip66/68/69/69k rated  now. 4- It has additional wifi chip in it, you won't drop signals and consistency will remain unlike other flagships. 5- It has newer touch sampling chip as well which makes user experience great and it matters for people who play games on mobile phones. 6- It has 165 hz now and it matters for gamers. However it gets activated only during gaming. During normal use, it switches between 1 and 120 only not 30,60,90 etc so yeah it makes user experience good. 7- Oxygen OS 16 is highly customizable and really good to use and this mindspace thing is actually nice and useful. Yeah, im a bit disappointed too because of camera's, it should be comparable to other flagships but it is not. Oneplus lags behind in camera but ig since they're associated with OPPO so their focus is now on performance/user experience side, while OPPO's focus is on camera and other stuff too like other flagships. Oneplus 15 Camera's are still good enough for daily use tbh but not at the level of other top flagships. If you want really good user experience, performance, customization, massive battery and somewhat above average camera then this is for you. If you want true high end camera's then but can compromise on some other things then you can for other brands. OxygenOS is really fun to use and remember, Iphone and samsung and pixel too still doesn't offer ip69 rating and Iphone's this year build is technically trash, can be easily scratched. Samsung is good and will always be a decent choice, pixel is good but trash at the same time since it lacks behind in literally every department except the cameras and OS. So yeah, think what you actually want from a cell phone and choose accordingly.  Correct me if I am wrong and missed something except the 1.5k resolution which really doesn't make much difference.

I feel like Oppo and OnePlus are now trying to separate their identities. Oppo is becoming more camera centric ğŸ“¸ and OnePlus is moving towards a gaming centric direction ğŸ®. But this is not the OnePlus we all knew before. OnePlus used to be the real flagship killer, the brand people trusted when there werenâ€™t strong competitors between Samsung and Apple. It created a huge impact in smartphone history.  Now Iâ€™m honestly disappointed with the direction OnePlus is taking. Gaming is not the main priority for everyone. If they really wanted to target gamers, they could have done it under the Nord series with something like a Nord GT. They could have still kept the main OnePlus lineup as the flagship killer it once was.  Since the UI is almost the same as Oppo with only small differences, many people will naturally shift to Oppo. And if someone wants the best camera performance with this UI, the Oppo Find X9 Ultra or Pro would be the best choice ğŸ“·ğŸ”¥. I think Oppo will now get the brand value that OnePlus once enjoyed.  I really appreciate Vivo and iQOO for what they are doing ğŸ™Œ. They even moved from Funtouch OS to Origin OS, and now people will finally trust them more in terms of software. Letâ€™s see what happens, but I donâ€™t think OnePlus will capture much of the market anymore except among gamers.  Vivo will probably do much better because of this shift from OnePlus. And even the Oppo Find X series, which never got enough attention before, will now start getting the recognition it deserves â­.  This is my point based on my knowledge, and I genuinely feel this is whatâ€™s going to happen.
The spirit of the super powerful OnePlus phone at a normal price has long been lost.

â€‹Â @RealTimeStrategy-GamesÂ Hi, I agree with you on many things. But I still feel Xiaomi, once the true budget king, has completely lost that crown. Now they are fully focused on the flagship segment and ignoring their budget users. Honestly, I do not recommend Xiaomi in the budget range anymore. I prefer recommending Infinix or even iQOO because they offer much better value for money. Realme is still decent to some extent. Xiaomi is no longer the budget king. ğŸ˜•  Parent companies always keep their brands separated. Oppo and Vivo are under BBK, but their user interface and strategies are completely different. Vivo already has the iQOO series for gamers and tech-focused users. Realme, in the last few years, has clearly positioned the GT series for performance lovers and gamers. So when these two gaming-focused lineups already exist, there is no need for OnePlus to shift in the same direction. ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸  OnePlus should have remained a brand-value smartphone series. Once upon a time, OnePlus was known for its camera quality and even surpassed Samsung in some models. They could have continued focusing on the camera and maintained that identity. Instead, they shifted towards gaming and performance, a space already covered by iQOO and Realme. This is exactly where my disappointment comes from. ğŸ˜”  The original vision of OnePlus was to offer the best all-round experience in display, camera, performance, build quality, speakers and haptics at a reasonable flagship price. That vision deserved appreciation. But now, with this strategy change, they are losing the uniqueness that made people love them. âœ¨  Coming to Huawei, it was one of my favourite brands. If it was not for US sanctions, Huawei would have become the number one smartphone brand in the world. I used Huawei flagships when they had Android and they were absolute beasts. Even though I had a more expensive phone like the Samsung Galaxy Note 3 in 2015, the Huawei phone I used at that time had better tuning and better camera performance. I still remember how it even surpassed the iPhone 8 when it launched. Huawei was on another level. ğŸ”¥  Honor is doing great now, but they need to expand globally. They make excellent smartphones, but availability in my country is the problem. I have to depend on places like UAE or Kuwait to get their devices. And yes, Honor sometimes has software glitches and camera inconsistencies. If they fix those and improve their optimization, Honor can truly become the next Huawei. ğŸ¤âœ¨  Overall, I am really disappointed with how OnePlus has shifted its strategy. ğŸ’”

But the cameras don't seem like that much of an upgrade I mean yes the telephoto and the ultra wide are higher resolution than on the 8T but is it really that much different? I feel like Android has been stuck in this very irregular computational photography and then any of a really good camera app. I think these companies have just been swapping out sensors but the software has mostly stayed similar. I do love the bypass charging though this will definitely make my phone last way longer so maybe the next Oneplus I'll buy is the Oneplus 25. What I really wanted was for the camera, even if the quality was lower to be more consistent But from all the footage that I looked at the footage seemed very shaky at best when it comes to video. I also really would have liked a macro mode that was as good as the Oneplus 8. Sadly no such phone has been made since a large mega pixel sensor with capability to do macrophotography. Any photos that are shot on the newer phones simply used a telephoto and you need to crop in to make it look like a micro while it really is not.   Another thing I feel like I'm really missing out on is desktop mode. It's coming it's in beta but still. The number one problem I do have though is cases since dbrand no longer makes them for oneplus. My best bet will be a spigen or something but unknown when it will come out if at all. Now with dbrand Only supporting Google Samsung and Apple for cases it makes it really difficult. Especially because the Samsung phones just horrible charging even if the S26 Ultra is going to get 60 Watt charging It is also going to be more expensive for the 512GB or 1TB version. Really wish you'd start using Wh instead of mAh for battery size. The OP15 actually has a 7.56v 3650mAh battery (27.6Wh). The 7300mAh is a fake rating assuming the dual cell battery was put in parallel instead of series. I've also seen phones list their actual mAh while having a 3.9v silicon-carbon battery, making them undersell their battery capacity. mAh is actually just a terrible way to depict power. It's like trying to measure the circumference of the earth using football fields, but using the median length of all the fields that exist in the closest country to a point on the measured circumference. Meaning if you're measuring somewhere in America it'll be X length, somewhere in Africa will be Y length, somewhere in Asia will be Z length, etc. Seems pretty confusing to measure the circumference of the earth in something that varies length doesnt it?

I use to take 3D photos whenever I can (with a regular phone it's only possible of still objects) and because of this deep depth of field is very important for me, and it's very annoying that most people say that a bigger camera sensor is better, but no, a bigger sensor is more light sensitive, but it comes with drawbacks, the depth of field gets shallower and almost all new flagship phone's camera has curved focal plane, which is a huge issue if you want to take 3D images or if you want to take a 2D close-up image of a flat surface, because in the latter scenario only the middle of the image will be in focus. (I've checked my iPhone 4S and its camera has flat focal plane as it should be, so it's possible to make such a camera, but that eighter would have way less light sensitivity or it would be very thick.)  So there is no better or worse phone camera, all they can do is change some specs and then the camera will be better in some scenarios but worse in others, the only way to actually make a better camera is to invent a new type of sensor which would be more light sensitive with the same sensor area. I also think that phone manufacturers eighter should have stopped at half inch sensors or if they want to go beyond that, then they must add physical variable aperture to the camera, releasing phones with 1 inch sensors and fixed aperture is one of the stupidest thing I've ever seen.

Everyone is different. I use my 1+10 Pro and Lightroom (color correction) or Resolve (on PC) to make insane quality pics and videos of our trips, and whether looking at the shot in the moment or later on socials, I always get comments about how great the quality is, what phone is that, etc.  I look back at pics & vids of my 12 yr old dogs as pups or a trip 10 years ago, and I notice the lower quality. I still like the memory reminder, but the "agh, those pics of Barcelona would look so much better if taken now" is real.  I think this will eventually be solved by a optional gallery filter that auto-upscales everything to best current quality.

@oneplus_india @oneplus @petelau  Subject: Feature Request â€“ Call End Tone via Earbuds & Power Button Behavior on Incoming Calls (OnePlus 12 / 13s) Dear OnePlus Team, Iâ€™m a OnePlus 12Â Â and 13s user and Iâ€™d like to highlight two important usability features that were available in earlier OnePlus devices (like the OnePlus 6), but are currently missing in newer models like the OnePlus 12 and 13R. These small enhancements can make a significant difference in user experience. 1. Call End Beep Sound via Earbuds or Bluetooth: When using earbuds or a Bluetooth headset during a call, there's no tone or audio feedback when the call ends. This feature existed on older OnePlus devices like the OnePlus 6. And Samsung galaxy s24, galaxy flip 7. Samsung phones currently offer this functionality with a "call end tone". Itâ€™s especially useful when the phone is in a pocket, bag, or placed away â€” users don't realize when the call has ended. Request: Please consider reintroducing the Call End Beep Tone (for Bluetooth/Earbud calls) feature in OxygenOS. 2. Power Button Function During Incoming Calls: When a call is ringing and the phone is on a table, pressing the power button immediately rejects the call, instead of simply turning off the screen. On the OnePlus 6 and Samsung galaxy s24 and Samsung flip 7, pressing the power button would just turn off the screen without disconnecting or rejecting the call. Samsung phones also behave similarly. This is especially useful during meetings, religious settings, or other quiet environments where one may want to silence the phone without rejecting the call. Request: Please consider adding a toggle option in OxygenOS for: â€œPress Power Button to Turn Off Screen Only (Donâ€™t End or Reject Call)â€ Thank you for continuing to build reliable, user-friendly devices. Bringing back these small, thoughtful features can further enhance the overall OnePlus experience. Kind regards, [Ashitosh] OnePlus 12, oneplus 13s User, maharashtra, India

I got the OnePlus 13 this year and its has been good but not great. The main problem I have is with Wifi 6 connectivity, on many networks the connection just cuts out and I have to turn off and on Wifi to get internet again. I read that it is a problem with the multi band steering router setting, I am not 100% sure but some posts say the 13 does not support this router feature for some reason. I have had to disable Wifi 6 to get stable performance and that is just awful. I haven't looked intro disabling the multi band steering on the router as its too much of headache to deal with, also all my other devices work fine with it and it is clearly a problem with the 13. Maybe them changing the modem has something to do with this, but maybe it still doesn't support multi ban steering, I kinda don't want to take the risk. Does anyone else have this problem on the 13? The rest of the 13 is great but everything I care about got upgraded on the 15, performance and battery, lower screen res for better battery, cheaper cameras are fine cause I don't care about them. Only thing lost is the easier to use alert slider, and I have the 13 without the glass back so its less prone to breaking. Honestly the 13 was a good value when I got it and a good upgrade from my OP6, but I I'm going to consider biting the bullet and getting the next Xperia when they re-design it, hopefully with the new battery technology and Qi2. I want the headphone jack back so much, I don't know if I'm stupid but every dongle that changes and has a headphone jack give feedback or the audio cuts out, I just don't know what I'm doing wrong...

I mean, sure, the cameras may not be as good as they can be, but let's be realistic here for a moment. The lower end of the spectrum on these expensive phones nowadays still take completely fine photos.  Maybe they cheaped out a little on the cameras this time, but if you took a step back, didn't look at the specs, didn't actively try to see that slight extra bit of noise and didn't have someone tell you the camera is "bad", you most likely wouldn't even notice or care. And if that one photo you took really matters to you, you're probably going to want to edit it anyway. Slap on some noise reduction, tweak the colors and you'll be fine. Don't be so dramatic.
That's just his opinion don't take it seriously lol

â€‹Â @christopher-Â i dont want to edit my photos. I want it authentic with a good focus. My s25 selfie camera is bad sometimes unless there is good lighting

Â @John99YTÂ  Not sure what you mean by "authentic". It's all mostly digital processing wether you edit or not. If what you mean is good straight out of the gate, that's pretty much an impossible task as everyone has different preference when it comes to how photos look. It can be objectively good on a technical level, but that doesn't mean it's to everyones taste.  My point is, most people just fill up their phone gallery without spending much time looking back at their photos, at which point, a photo being a little soft at the edges doesn't matter. And if they do, they look at it on their small phone screen, and it's the photo itself that matters, the memory, not as much the technical quality. If you happen to be one of the people that saves or prints photos you took with your phone, you're gonna want to shoot raw and edit anyway. Especially with printing, because it sure as hell won't come out looking the way you expect otherwise.  Sorry if i'm harsh here, but i feel like most people that complain about photo quality in modern smartphones are just spec-nerds and pixel peepers that care less about why they take a photo, and more about being able to show a friend how "crisp and high quality" photos their phone can take. If you really care about good photos, you probably have a decent camera already. I understand the convenience of a phone, but that convenience is always going to have a cost.

Â @u_n_c_l_e_m_i_s_oÂ  Reliability, lol. I've had one Pixel phone (Pixel Fold) and it was by far the most unreliable phone I've ever had. The network (cellular and WiFi) would randomly drop out, the flashlight function stopped working after an update, then got fixed months later after another update, the phone stopped launching the Wix Dashboard app after a few months, even after reinstalling the app and resetting the phone to factory defaults, it still wouldn't launch the Wix app. And it wouldn't even read a flash drive that I plugged in to try and backup the photos with, and that flash drive works with zero issues on every other phone I have plugged it into.   But the worst offender is that an update came through and completely bricked the outer screen. The screen was working fine, than I installed an update and what do you know, my outer screen is disabled. I could turn off the phone, close it then boot it back up and the outer screen turns on and the boot logo shows, but as soon as it's done booting it turns black and I can only use the inner screen. These were all software issues too, so the excuse of it being a first gen hardware issue doesn't fly, especially when I was looking up these issues and found other people with different Pixel phones having the same problems.

Me too! I am rocking a 9 year old Oneplus 3T and was waiting for the 15 to drop to decide if I buy the 13 or the 15, but the crappy cameras and the loss of the alert slider is a deal breaker for me. A couple of days ago saw photo samples of the 15 on gsmarena and I already noticed the awful quality. Now that Marques confirmed it, I know which one I'll buy. The Oneplus 13 is a great phone and hopefully prices will drop a little now that the 15 is released.

Â @Mamoo-01Â  But what is the point of switching to the OnePlus 15 and the 165Hz is just marketing and unnecessary, 120Hz is enough and they even boast about the display that it is better than the OnePlus 13 but it is not, it is worse, it is the worst model they have ever made and a terrible failure, only the battery is bigger and the screen is flat, but I like the screen in the OnePlus 13 more.

â€‹Â @markpolo7Â exactly! That's also why I've decided to get the 13. It is still a great phone even if it has the 1 year old snapdragon chip, and the 15's upgrades aren't useful to me.
